About KADET: The Kenya Agency for the Development of Enterprise and Technology (KADET) is committed to economically empowering its clients by providing financial services to rural communities in order to relieve suffering and improve living conditions within those communities.

loans.use: To increase the stock of ladies' trousers in his shop, as well as to buy bulbs, aerials and wires for his electronics shop

loans.name: Juan Jose

texts.es: El señor Juan José C. tiene la edad de 65 años,  habita en el barrio Pablo Calero, junto a su esposa la cual le apoya con las actividades del hogar, ellos tiene cinco hijos ya todos independientes, los planes hacia su familia es mejorar las condiciones de vida, don Juan desde hace 40 años se dedica a la agricultura la mayor dificultad que se le presenta es la perdida del cultivo por robo,  los planes futuros hacia su cultivo es diversificarlo. Con el préstamo va a comprar fertilizantes e insumos para mejorar la producción.Da las gracias a la institucion por el prestamo ya que podra mejorar el cultivo
texts.en:
Señor Juan José C. is 65 and lives in the Pablo Calero neighborhood with his wife, who helps him with their home's chores. They have 5 children, who are all independent. Their plans for their family are to improve their living conditions. Juan has practiced agriculture for 40 years. The biggest problem that he faces is the loss of his production to theft. His plans for his crops are to diversify them. With this loan, he will purchase more fertilizers and supplies to improve his production. He is thankful to the microfinance institution for this loan so he can improve his crops.

Translated from Spanish by Tanya Harper, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer

loans.name: Honest Group

texts.en:
These people are Kadiatu K., Fatmata K., and Mabinty K.. They called their group 'Honest Group'. This will be the fourth loan these entrepreneurs are receiving from SMT. Previous loans have created a huge and a very significant impact into the lives and living standards of these borrowers. Having repaid their last loan successfully, they are again asking for a new loan of Le 800,000 for each to further strengthen their businesses.

Kadiatu K. (left) is the leader of this group. Kadiatu is age forty-seven, married to a businessman; they have four children. One of her children has just sat to the West Africa Senior Secondary Schools Examinations, two are in Junior Secondary School III, and the last is in class four. Kadiatu sells cooked rice and has been in this business for over thirty years now. With this loan, she will be able to buy cooking ingredients like rice and palm oil (the most popular cooking oil) wholesale.

loans.use: Invest in her business

loans.name: Marina

texts.en:
Marina R. owns and operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop selling both food and daily use products in her community. She is 36 years old, married and has two school-age children. They are from the village of Kabuhi, Camiguin. Marina has been in her business for over three years and earns approximately 3000 PHP a month.

In 2007, Marina joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living conditions and enable her to engage in business activities. Marina is requesting a loan of 4000 PHP which will be used to purchase products to sell. This will be Marina's first loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue to improve and expand her business.

About HSPFI: HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Crecelia

texts.es:
Crecelia es socia del Banco Comunal Llamkasun que significa Trabajemos.
Crecelia es conviviente, tiene 29 años y 4 hijos, Creselia vende carne al por mayor, los animales los adquiere en las diferentes ferias de la región.
Crecelia necesita un préstamo de 1500 soles dinero que será invertido en la compra de animales.
Los sueños de Crecelia son tener un puesto estable y brindar una buena educación a sus hijos.
texts.en:
Crecelia is a partner in the Llamkasun Communal Bank. Llamkasun means "we work". Crecelia is a 29 year old woman. She lives with her 4 children and their father. Creselia sells wholesale meat, acquiring livestock from different markets around the area. Crecelia is requesting a 1500 sol loan which she will invest in the purchase of livestock. Crecelia dreams of one day having a permanent stand and of offering her children a good education.

Translated from Spanish by James Comstock, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Livestock purchase

loans.name: Filomeno

texts.es:
Filomeno esta dedicado a la crianza de ganado vacuno, cuya producción de leche la comercializa a Pil Andina (Planta Industrializadora de Leche); como segundo ingreso Filomeno trabaja como conductor de tractor prestando servicios en su comunidad realizando trabajos de arado y siembra.
Su esposa Natividad se dedica al cuidado de sus hijos los cuales se encuentran en edad escolar, a su esposo le colabora en el cuidado del ganado.
Su residencia es en la localidad de Chojñacollo en la Provincia los Andes ubicado a cinco horas de la Ciudad de La Paz.

El crédito lo destinara en la compra de una vaca lechera y así incrementar tanto sus ingresos como su  producción de leche.

Es el primer crédito con IMPRO, la evaluación realizada califica para la aprobación del préstamo solicitado por Filomeno.
texts.en:
Filomeno raises cattle whose milk production he sells to PIL Andina (the Andean Milk Processing Plant). He also works as a tractor driver plowing and sowing the fields in his community.

His wife, Natividad, takes care of their children who are of school age and she helps her husband taking care of the cattle.

Their home is in Chojñacollo, in the Province of los Andes located five hours of the city of La Paz.

The loan will be used to buy a milking cow to increase their income as well as their milk production.

This is Filomeno’s first loan with IMPRO (Kiva’s field partner) his evaluation has qualified him for this loan.

Translated from Spanish by Mayra Duque, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy a milking cow to increase milk production.

loans.name: Onn

texts.en:
Onn C., age 52, and his wife, Roeun Chheang, age 46, have been married since 1982. They have nine children: four sons and five daughters. Two of them are married and live away from the family home.  Three children are garment factory workers and the others are in school. Their family lives approximately fifteen kilometers from Phnom Penh.

Onn and his wife have been farming for 10 years. They grow many kinds of vegetable on their own farmland behind their house. The couple doesn’t have enough capital to sustain their farm. Onn requests his first loan of $500 for working capital.

loans.use: Capital for farm operation.

loans.name: Kamel

texts.en:
Kamel is a 50-year-old man who lives in Saida, Southem Lebanon, with his wife and four children. Kamel has been selling roasters and charcoal for 29 years. He has requested a loan from Kiva partner Al Majmoua in order to purchase a roaster for his work. Kamel has been a micro-credit client for five years now and has always repaid on time.

Kamel is successful in his work because he charges competitive prices and sells his products wholesale. His clients are his friends and neighbors. When he first started his business, he didn’t face difficulties. Kamel set up this business because he wanted to be independent in his work, and there is high customer demand in his region. In future, he plans on improving his business.

loans.use: To purchase a roaster

loans.name: Chanthorn

texts.en:
Mrs. Chanthorn P., 26 and her husband, Mr. Sinoeun Cheng, 25, live on an island of the Mekong River about 15 kilometers from Phnom Penh. They were married in 2005 and have just one young daughter. In the past, the couple worked as silk weavers. However, because traders are paying less for the finished fabric, they stopped the business and run a new business as well. 

Chanthorn is a chef; she cooks for a restaurant in Phnom Penh. Mr. Sinoeun Cheng has full-time employment in Phnom Penh as well. Unfortunately, the couple doesn’t have their own transportation to travel to work. That's why Chanthorn is requesting a loan of $700 to purchase a motorbike for commuting.

loans.use: To purchase a motorbike for commuting to work.

loans.name: Rosalia

texts.es:
La señora Rosalía es socia del Banco Comunal “Santa Rosa de Lima - Juli” desde hace 9 años atrás, del distrito de Juli, provincia de Chucuito, departamento de Puno. Ella tiene 49 años de edad, cuenta con estudios secundarios incompletos, es casada y tiene 6 hijos.
Rosalía se dedica a la venta de artesanìas y nos cuenta que con el primer préstamo solicitado al Movimiento Manuela Ramos que fue de S/. 300.00 nuevos soles compró todos los materiales para hacer las artesanías.
Ella solicitará un crédito de S/. 1,500.00 nuevos soles con los que podrá comprar lana, plumón, bayeta.
Su sueño para el futuro es tener su casa propia y comprarse su carro. 
Lo que más le gusta de su Banco Comunal es el ahorro.
texts.en:
Ms. Rosalía has been a member of the Community Bank “Santa Rosa de Lima - Juli” for 9 years. She’s from the Juli district, Chucuito province, Puno department. She is 49 years old and has an incomplete high school education. She is married and has 6 children. Rosalía sells handicrafts and she tells us that with the first loan requested for the Manuela Ramos Movement for S/. 300.00 nuevos, she bought all the materials to make the handicrafts. She is requesting a loan of S/. 1,500.00 nuevos soles so she can buy wool, down (feather), cloth. Her dream for the future is to have her own house and to buy a car. What she likes most about her Community Bank are the saving opportunities.

Translated from Spanish by Lauren Jackson, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy wool, down (feather), cloth

loans.name: Céline Ohoué

texts.fr: H. Céline Ohoué est née en 1957 à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin. Céline Ohoué vit à Agblangandan, dans la commune de Sèmè-Podji, depuis environs 35 ans. Mariée à HOUSSA Simon, un tailleur, Céline Ohoué est mère de quatre enfants, tous scolarisés. Céline Ohoué a un autre enfant à charge. La famille vit ensemble à Agblangandan. Le couple assure ensemble les charges de la famille. Céline Ohoué n'a jamais été à l'école. Depuis environs 25 ans, Céline Ohoué mène comme activité, la vente de "pur water", de l'eau de pompe. Céline Ohoué a également un moulin à tomate qu'elle gère à son domicile. C'est à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin, que Céline Ohoué s'approvisionne. C'est une ancienne cliente de ALIDé, ayant déjà bénéficié de cinq crédits auprès de ALIDé. Tous ces crédits ont été bien remboursés. Céline Ohoué sollicite un sixième crédit auprès de ALIDé, en vue de renforcer ses activités, pour mieux faire face à la demande de sa clientèle.
texts.en:
Céline Ohoué H. was born in 1957 in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. She has lived in Agblangandan, in the Sèmè-Podji region, for the past 35 years. She is married to Simon Houssa, a tailor, and is the mother of four school-age children, with another child also in her care. The family lives together in Agblangandan and the couple share the responsibilities of looking after their family. Céline Ohoué never went to school. For the past 25 years Céline Ohoué has sold 'pure water', pumpwater, for a living. She also owns a tomato press that she runs from home. She sources her goods from the Benin international market. She is an existing client of ALIDé, having already received five loans, which have all been repaid successfully. Céline Ohoué is seeking a sixth loan from ALIDé in order to invest in her business to help meet customer demand.

Translated from French by Danielle Treharne, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchasing containers for water and spare parts for a press

loans.name: En

texts.en: En R., 42, is married and lives with his three children in Dangkao, Cambodia. R. is a skillful blacksmith in his village. He is able to earn an income of USD $3 per day to help cover the family expenses. He has been engaged in this business since 2000. His wife (pictured here) works at home to prepare fabrics with her children, earning an income of USD $1 per day. R. and his wife try to work hard and help each other to ensure a good standard of living for the family. And they are seeking to improve their businesses as well. As a result, R. is requesting a loan of US $500 from CREDIT, Kiva’s partner. He wants to use the loan to buy metal to make roofs for his customers. This is his first loan from CREDIT.

loans.use: To buy metal to make roofs

loans.name: Color Esperanza Group

texts.es:
El Banco Comunal Color Esperanza, inicia su segundo ciclo con 15 socias. 

Las socias realizan diferentes negocios como la venta de abarrotes en general, Cereales, chicha, quesos, ropa, animales menores, panes, también brindan servicio de transporte.

Como es el caso de la señora Sandra que es conviviente, tiene 23 años y 2 hijos, Sandra tiene una tienda en su casa en donde vende abarrotes en general, carnes, verduras, artículos de librería, actividad que realiza todos los días. Con el préstamo que obtendrá Sandra comprara arroz, azúcar y útiles escolares.

Mientras que Alejandra es conviviente, tiene 35 años y 6 hijos, Alejandra vende cancha de maíz, fideo, arroz de manera ambulatoria al frente de un mini hospital, actividad que realiza todos los días, Con el préstamo que obtendrá Alejandra comprara canchas surtidas.

Las socias necesitan diferentes montos de prestamos como 300 soles, 600soles, 750 soles, 1000 soles  haciendo un total de 10,750 soles de prestamos en el Banco Comunal. 

Sus prestamos serán invertidos en la compra de arroz, azúcar, útiles escolares, canchas, cereales, quesos, ropa y animales.

Los sueños de las socias son Ampliar sus negocios, sus hijos culminen sus estudios, tener casa propia.
texts.en:
The communal bank Color Esperanza started its second loan cycle with 15 members. The members are in different businesses, such as the sale of foodstuffs, cereals, chicha (a Peruvian drink), cheese, clothing, small animals, and breads. They also have transportation services. For example, there is Ms Sandra who is in a common-law marriage. She is 23 and has two children. Sandra has a store in her house where she works every day selling groceries, meat, vegetables, stationery and books. With the loan Sandra will buy rice, sugar and school supplies. Alejandra is another member, in a common-law marriage, 35 and with 6 children. She also works every day selling cancha (corn kernels used for snacks), pasta, and rice, as a street vendor in front of a mini hospital. Alejandra will use the loan to buy assorted canchas. The members need different loan amounts, like 300 soles, 600 soles, 750 soles, and 1000 soles, for a total of 10,750 soles from the communal bank. Their loans will be used to buy rice, sugar, school supplies, canchas, cereals, cheese, clothing and animals. The dreams of the members are to increase their businesses, for their children to finish their studies, and to have their own homes.

Translated from Spanish by Miriam Palacio, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy rice, sugar, school supplies, canchas (corn kernels), cereals, cheese, clothing, and small animals

loans.name: Francisca

texts.fr: M. Francisca est née vers 1962 et vit au quartier Agla à Cotonou, capitale économique du Bénin.  Mariée à TOGNI Martin, un électricien, Francisca est mère de trois enfants, tous scolarisés.  Francisca vit ensemble avec ses enfants et son mari.  Le couple supporte ensemble les charges de la famille. Francisca a arrêté les classes au cours primaire.  Il y a environs 15 ans que Francisca s’est mise à vendre de maïs et de haricot à Dantokpa, marché international du Bénin, et à son domicile.  Aussi elle vend de la tomate fraîche. C’est à Glazoué et Djoda que Francisca s’approvisionne.  Francisca a déjà obtenu deux crédits à ALIDé – ces crédits ont été bien remboursés.  Elle sollicite un autre crédit auprès de ALIDé pour renforcer ses activités et mieux répondre à la forte demande de sa clientèle. Plus tard, Francisca ambitionne acheter une parcelle.
texts.en:
M. Francisca was born around 1962 and lives in the Agla district in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin.  Married to TOGNI Martin, an electrician, she is the mother of three children, who are all in school.  She lives together with her children and husband.  The couple jointly support the family.  Francisca dropped out of primary school.  About fifteen years ago, she started selling corn and beans at Dantokpa, the international market of Benin, and out of her home.  She also sells fresh tomatoes.  She gets her supplies in Glazoué and Djoda.  She has already obtained two loans from ALIDé -- these loans have been repaid.  Francisca is requesting another loan from ALIDé for bolstering her business and for responding better to strong customer demand.  Her ambition is to buy a plot of land later on.

Translated from French by Dan Kuey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Bolstering her business and buying staple foods and fresh tomatoes

loans.name: Mom

texts.en:
Mom M. is aged 40. She resides in Dongkor District, about 10 km from Phnom Penh city. Her husband is shown in the photo.

Mom M. has a job sewing clothing in a garment factory and earns a specific salary. This income is used towards caring for her two young kids while her third child is married and lives independently.

The other source of family income comes from her husband’s work selling charcoal and he is also a construction worker. Beside their current work, they have also always operated a rice cultivating business.

Mom M. is taking out her loan to accumulate a larger amount of charcoal for her husband to sell and will use the rest to buy a water pump to irrigate her crop and pump water for her family's use.

loans.use: To accumulate a larger amount of charcoal for her husband's business and to buy a water pump

loans.name: Muhammadjon

texts.ru: Юсупов Мухаммаджон проживает в районе Шахритуз. Возраст, 38 лет. Женат, имеет 5 детей. Жена, домохозяйка. Сам Мухаммаджон более 10 лет занимается растениеводством. При доме имеет земельный участок, где сажает арбуз. Кредит берет для закупа семян и минеральных удобрений. Мухаммаджон хочет посеить и получить хороший урожай для продажи.
texts.en:
Muhammadjon Y. lives in the Shahrituz district. He is 38 years old, married and has 5 children. His wife is a homemaker. Muhammadjon has been involved in agriculture for over 10 years. He has a plot of land by his house, where he grows watermelons. He is requesting the loan for the purchase of seeds and mineral fertilizers. Muhammadjon wants to sow and get a good harvest for sale.

Translated from Russian by Anna Sorokina-Hailey, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of seeds and mineral fertilizers

loans.name: Flordeliza

texts.en:
Flordeliza B. is from the village of Magsaysay, Misamis Oriental. She is 29 years old. Flordeliza is separated from her spouse and has two infant children. To make a living, Flordeliza owns & operates a sari-sari (variety) retail shop selling a variety of snack products in the local community. Flordeliza has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month for these activities.

Flordeliza joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Flordeliza is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase additional products to sell. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Flordeliza from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement the family's income. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase additional products to sell

loans.name: Rebecca

texts.en: Rebecca F. is a sari-sari (general) store owner. She sells variety of goods in her local community and uses all her income to support the needs of her family. She earned enough in her business but still need additional capital to cater to the needs of her customers. She would like to apply for a loan from Community Economic Ventures Inc. She will use the loan to buy additional merchandise to resell. She likes the CEVI credit services because it has only 2% interest rate, which is very affordable to repay.

loans.use: to buy oroducts for resale

loans.name: Libertad Group

texts.es:
El Banco Comunal Libertad inicia su séptimo ciclo con 17 socias. 
Las socias realizan diferentes negocios como la venta D. ropa, frutas, comida, lencería, juguetes, mercería, miel D. abeja y artesanías.
Como es el caso D. la Señora Odilia que es la presidenta del Banco Comunal, Odilia es casada, tiene 63 años y 3 hijos, Odilia venD. miel D. abeja que compra en los diferentes pueblos D. la región, sus ventas los realiza en instituciones y mercados. Además Odilia venD. ropas interiores que ofrece a diferentes clientes. Su préstamo será invertido en la compra D. miel. Los sueños D. Odilia son mejorar su negocio y que su ultima hija culmine sus estudios D. Contabilidad. 
Las socias necesitan diferentes montos D. prestamos como 450 soles, 600 soles, 900 soles haciendo un total D. 13,600 soles.
texts.en:
The Communal Bank “Libertad” (Freedom) is starting its seventh loan cycle with 17 members. They engage in different businesses selling clothing, fruit, food, lingerie, toys, sewing supplies, honey, and handicrafts.

Such is the case with Sra. Odilia, the Communal Bank president. Odilia is 63 years old, married, and has three children. She sells honey that she acquires from different villages in the region. Her products are sold to institutions and markets. In addition, she sells undergarments to different customers. Her loan will be invested in the purchase of honey. Odilia dreams of improving her business and seeing her youngest daughter finish her degree in accounting.

The members need different loan amounts ranging from 450 PEN, 600 PEN, to 900 PEN, for a grand total of 13,600 PEN to the entire Communal Bank.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase honey

loans.name: Emelie

texts.en:
Emelie E. is from the village of Pinamulaan, Banisilan, South Cotabato. She is 48 years old, married, and has five school-aged children. To make a living, Emelie owns and operates a business providing trucking services to local community members by transporting agricultural products to the city and to the neighboring barangays. Emelie has been engaged in her business for over three years and earns approximately 8,000 PHP per month from these activities.
In 2009, Emelie joined Kiva partner, HSPFI, to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from HSPFI. This loan was used to repair a transport vehicle used in the business. Emelie is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP, which will be used to buy materials and equipment needed to repair a transport vehicle used in the business. This loan will be her third from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to support her children's education.

About HSPFI
HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To repair a transport vehicle used in the business

loans.name: Vertimano

texts.en: Vertimano L. is currently in the business of selling rice and beans at the market and is requesting a loan to stock more bags of rice and beans to sell. Vertimano is 29 years old and is married with a husband who is a soldier. She has 3 children and her children go to school. With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to build up a store for her goods. About BRAC BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, human rights and legal services, which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: Stock more bags of rice and beans to sell

loans.name: Evangeline

texts.en:
Evangeline A. is a 53-year old married woman who supports her family by operating a fishing business.  She lives in Purok 3, Brgy. Linaon, Cauayan, Negros Occidental. 

She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 1999 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts.  By working hard in her fishing business, she is gradually making her family more economically stable.  She now earns an average income of PHP20,000. 

Evangeline is now borrowing PHP 25,000 so she can build a new pump boat.  This will be her 14th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP22,000, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey towards economic freedom.  Evangeline aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future well being by following the Dungganon way. 

--------------------------------------------------
About NWTF:  In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work.

loans.use: Additional Working Capital

loans.name: Bahadur's Group

texts.en: Bahadur lives in Chichawatni in Pakistan with her husband and a son in a three-room brick house. Her husband is a laborer but his earnings are not enough to fully support the family. She is a housewife and stays at home to take care of her cattle. She buys young animals, raises them and then sells them in the nearby communities to earn a good profit.  She is always ready to support her family in any way possible. She has applied for a loan for the first time from Asasah to help her son who wants to expand his fruit-selling business by purchasing more seasonal fruits. Bahadur is hopeful that her son will be able to improve his business with the help of a loan and as a result, her family’s living standard will improve.

loans.use: To purchase seasonal fruits

loans.name: Cruz Esperanza

texts.es:
Cruz Esperanza tiene 33 años de edad, es madre soltera y tiene un pequeño hijo, vive en el caserío El Huantaco, un centro poblado del área rural del distrito agrícola de Tambogrande, una zona dedicada principalmente  al cultivo de árboles frutales, se encuentra en la provincia de Piura y pertenece a la región del mismo nombre, se  localiza a mas de tres horas de la ciudad de Chiclayo.

Se dedica a vender artículos de primera necesidad y abarrotes en una bodega instalada en el domicilio donde reside, este negocio le permite a sus clientes y vecinos contar con productos de uso diario al alcance de la mano, por lo que su negocio cuenta con bastante clientela, las ganancias que percibe de esta actividad las utiliza en solventar sus gastos personales y cuidar se su pequeño niño.	

Ella desea ampliar su negocio comprando mas artículos para aumentar su stock y también aumentar su nivel de ventas. Por ello se ha visto en la necesidad de solicitar por primera vez a Edpyme Alternativa un crédito de 2000 nuevos soles que  le ayuden a lograr su meta.

Cruz es una mujer honrada y bastante trabajadora. En la zona donde reside sus vecinos y conocidos le consideran una persona tranquila y de confianza. Su mayor anhelo es poder brindarle a su hijo la oportunidad de tener una mejor calidad de vida.
texts.en:
Cruz Esperanza is a 33-year-old single mother with a small child. She lives in the El Huantaco hamlet, a rural community in the agricultural district of Tambogrande, a region where there is mainly fruit tree cultivation. This place is located in the Piura province, and is a part of the region that goes by the same name. It is located more than three hours from the city of Chiclayo.

She sells basic need items and provisions from home. This business allows her customers and neighbors to have easy access to daily use products, which is why she has a solid client base. She uses the profits earned from this business to cover her personal expenses and to support her young child.

She wishes to expand her business by purchasing more goods and increasing her stock, thus boosting sales. For this reason, she feels the need to request a 2,000.00 PEN loan from Edpyme Alternativa for the first time so that she can reach her goal.

Cruz is an honest and hard-working woman. Her neighbors and acquaintances in the area consider her to be a calm and trustworthy person. Her greatest wish is to be able to grant her child the opportunity to have a better quality of life.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase basic need items and other provisions to expand her in-home general store

loans.name: Benigno Ricardo

texts.es:
El señor Benigno Ricardo G. P., es zapatero se dedica a la reparación y elaboración de zapatos, tiene un tramo en el sector del bisne desde hace mas de 10 años, es casado y tiene dos hijos en edades escolares, habita en el barrio la Resistencia de la Escuela la Normal 2c al sur, ½ c abajo ½ c al sur.

El señor Benigno G. P., solicita crédito para compra de materiales para la reparación y elaboración de zapatos ya que hace zapatos Ortopédicos, Botas de Cuero, etc, según el estilo que el clienta quiera, ya lleva 28 créditos con CEPRODEL y ha demostrado ser muy responsable y  cumplido en sus pagos.
texts.en:
Benigno Ricardo G. P. is a shoemaker who repairs and manufactures shoes and has had a shop in the Bisne sector for the past ten years. He’s married, has two school-aged children, and lives in the Resistencia neighborhood; two blocks to the south and 1/2 block below then 1/2 block south of the Normal school. Benigno is asking for this loan in order to buy supplies for the manufacture and repair of shoes. He makes orthopedic shoes, leather boots, etc; whatever the customer wants. He has had 28 prior loans through CEPRODEL and has proven himself to be responsible with his payments.

Translated from Spanish by Hugo Reyes, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Supplies

loans.name: Luciana

texts.en:
Luciana C., a 47 year old who has a common law husband, supports her family by operating two business ventures:  egg retailing and pig fattening.  She lives in Barangay Looc, Santander, Cebu. She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2005 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her egg retailing and pig fattening businesses, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of $273. 

Luciana is now borrowing 24,000 PHP for the purchase of a motorcycle for egg delivery. This will be her 8th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of 24,000 PHP, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. Luciana aspires to elevate her family's living conditions and ensure their future well being by following the Dungganon way.

The above photo of Luciana C. was taken in her home. 

About NWTF: 

In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed to a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: Purchase of new motorcycle for egg delivery

loans.name: Zenaida

texts.en: Zenaida M. is from the village of Alinam, Cauayan City, Isabela. She is 43 years old and is married with five school-aged children. Zenaida owns and operates a business raising pigs for fattening and sale. She has been engaged in her business for over two years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP when she sells a raised animal. In 2007, Zenaida joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase piglets to raise and sell. Zenaida is requesting a new loan of 12,000 PHP which will again be used to purchase piglets to raise and sell. This loan will be her 8th from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve and expand her business. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has twenty-one branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small-business entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase piglets to raise and sell

loans.name: Pole Pole Development Group-Jinja

texts.en: Sixty-eight-year-old Yasin K. belongs to the Pole Pole Group-Jinja. He is father to eight kids and runs a six-year-old retail shop. Customers to his shop vary, but it’s mostly fishermen who patronize his shop. His business got its foothold with savings from a farming business. From the onset, he has exhibited hard work and it has brought him rewards. In a week, he is able to make 100,000 shillings and with this loan, he wants to buy tomato seeds that he will plant. After harvesting, he says he will sell the produce.

loans.use: The purchase of tomato seeds that he will plant

loans.name: San

texts.en:
Mrs. San T. is a married woman, aged 35, and she and her husband have four lovely children. Three of them are single, and one is married. Mrs. San T. is a local farmer and plate-seller in front of her house. The most of her customers are retailers at her local market. She has a life partner in her husband who has a motorcycle to run a taxi service, picking up tourists who want to visit Angkor Wat Temple, or anywhere else in town. 

This family normally earns an average of US$ 7 per day to help cover their family’s daily living expenses. Presently, she is concerned that her husband's motorbike is getting old and breaks down very often. This has caused frequent interruptions to her husband's operations. Therefore, Mrs. San T. would like a loan of US$ 1200 to buy a used motorbike for her husband’s business.

loans.use: To buy a used motorbike for her husband’s business

loans.name: Pamela

texts.en:
Pamela N. lives in the Kanyanya neighborhood in the city of Kampala, Uganda.  She is married and has two children, both of whom are in school. Pamela has a business of selling sweet potatoes. She has been in this business for four years and she works one day out of every week. Pamela sells her products at the market, by means of wholesale/retail.     

Pamela has requested a loan of 500,000 Ugandan Shillings from MCDT SACCO, which she will use to buy more bags of sweet potatoes. The main business challenges for Pamela include transportation and seasonality.  Her goals and aspirations for her business are to start selling on a wholesale basis only.    

Pamela lives in a home that she rents; she has access to electricity and piped water. Her major monthly expenses include food, school fees and rent.

loans.use: To buy more bags of sweet potatoes

loans.name: Gulkaiyr Kuban Kyzy's Group

texts.en:
Gulkaiyr is 35 years old and married. Her husband works for the Ministry of Internal Affairs. The couple is raising a daughter who is a teenager and goes to school. 

In order to earn extra money to cover family expenses the Gulkaiyr started to breed cattle. Later Gulkaiyr’s brother became a family partner who helped operate the business. Out of profits the family has noticeably improved their financial position.

Now in order to obtain a horse for further fattening and resale Gulkaiyr hopes to obtain a loan. Then her plans including automobile buying. 

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: To purchase a horse

loans.name: Oyunchimeg

texts.en:
Oyunchimeg is a 53-year-old, single mother who lives with her daughter in small wooden house in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. 

She has been operating a used clothes retail business since 2008 with her daughter. Her store is located next to her home. After succeeding to achieve stable operations, she used her earnings to purchase construction materials to fix her house.  

This is her sixth Kiva loan through Credit Mongol. She is planning to build a bigger grocery store in her yard. She has good communication skills and her business is very important to her. She is requesting loan to purchase some more clothes and increase her working capital.

loans.use: Purchase more clothing to sell and to increase her working capital

loans.name: Jenny Fernanda

texts.es: Jenny R. P. es una joven de 25 años que aprendió de su madre a ser independiente y a ser capaz de generar ingresos para si misma y para su crecimiento personal;  su ejemplo  fue el impulso que Jenny recibió durante su infancia,  para que en el año 2008, iniciara una forma de ganar dinero y ser autosuficiente, emprendiendo negocios que su capacidad observadora le permite visualizar como rentables; es así como  vende artesanías que produce en su propio  taller como mochilas y bolsos, que en la actualidad  exhibe en su miscelánea en su propia casa,  a la cual ha agregado gradualmente otros productos como calzado, repuestos y muchos artículos  que la gente necesita en su rutina diaria.  Así mismo Jenny R. vende arepas, carimañolas y otras frituras en la puerta de su casa diariamente, y también como realizó un curso de mantenimiento y reparación de celulares, aprovecha este conocimiento para ofrecer este mismo servicio, que le ha facilitado el saber negociar estos equipos, vender sus repuestos, carcasas, teclados, forros.  Los ingresos netos por este negocio  son de $550.000 COP, los cuales   representan un 30% de utilidad sobre la venta; con estos ingresos apoya  los gastos familiares y ha logrado pagar su educación como tecnóloga en mercadotecnia y que desea finalizar con mucho éxito. Su credikiva es el primer financiamiento con la Fundación Mario Santo Domingo, con él planea comprar un equipo de cómputo para mejorar y ampliar la gama de diseños y controlar mejor sus tareas diarias en sus negocios.
texts.en:
Jenny R. P. is a 25 year-old woman who learned from her mother how to be independent and make income for herself and for her personal growth.  It was her mother's example that Jenny observed during her childhood that spurred her, in 2008, to start earning her own money and become self-sufficient, starting businesses that her observant nature allowed her to see as profitable.

Jenny started out selling handicrafts that she produces in her own workshop such as backpacks and bags.  She currently displays her products in the general store she has in her own home.  She has gradually added other products such as footwear, spare parts and many articles that people need in their daily lives.

Jenny also sells 'arepas' (corn pancakes), 'carimañolas' (traditional Colombian fritters stuffed with cheese and meat and fried) and other fried food from the door of her home every day.  She has also taken a course on servicing and fixing cell phones and taken advantage of the knowledge she gained to start offering this service too.  She knows how to do business with these items and sell spare parts, cases, keyboards and covers for them.  Jenny's net profits for this business are 550,000 Colombian pesos which represent a 30% sales profit.  She uses her profits to support her family's expenses and has managed to pay for her education as a marketing technologist.  She hopes to finish this course successfully.

Jenny's Kiva loan is her first loan with Fundación Santo Domingo.  She plans to use it to buy a computer so that she can improve and expand her range of designs and better control her daily tasks in her businesses.

loans.use: To buy a computer so that she can improve and expand her range of designs and better control her daily tasks in her businesses

loans.name: Guadalupe

texts.es:
La socia pertenece al banco comunal “COMUZONE I”; El banco está ubicado en el distrito de Cusco, perteneciente a la provincia de Cusco y departamento de Cusco.

La socia es la Sra. Guadalupe; ella tiene 34 años de edad y es conviviente y tiene 3 hijos; La socia alterna sus actividades diarias con el negocio de venta de carne, ella tiene un puesto en el mercado, ella atiende desde las 5:00 a.m hasta las 6:00 p.m,la socia quiere ampliar y mejorar el negocio, ahora que se acercan las fiestas navideñas venderá carne de cerdo. La socia solicita el préstamo para comprar carne de cerdo al por mayor.

La socia está feliz por el préstamo y se compromete a cumplir con los pagos de su cuota.
texts.en:
Guadalupe belongs to the “COMUZONE I” Communal Bank, located in the district, province and department of Cusco. 

She is 34 years old, living with her partner and has 3 children. Guadalupe's daily activity centers on her meat-selling business. She has a post in the market which she attends from 5:00 am until 6:00 pm. Guadalupe wants to expand and improve her business. Now that the Christmas season is approaching she will sell more pork. She is requesting the loan to buy pork at wholesale.

Guadalupe is happy with the loan and she promises to comply with the terms of repayment.

loans.use: TO BUY PORK AT WHOLESALE TO SELL

loans.name: Ma. Sol

texts.en:
Ma. Sol is a 52-year-old single woman who supports her family by operating two business ventures: a general store and a restaurant businesses. She lives in Kabankalan City, Negros Occidental. 

She has been a member of NWTF-Project Dungganon since 2005 and has improved her living conditions with the help of her loans from NWTF and through her own efforts. By working hard in her general store and restaurant businesses, she is gradually making her family more economically stable. She now earns an average monthly income of PHP 20,000. 

Ma. Sol is borrowing PHP 30,000 so that she can purchase more stock to sell. This will be her 17th loan from NWTF-Project Dungganon. Her previous loan of PHP 29,500, which she paid off well within its term, was just another step in her journey toward economic freedom. 

Ma. Sol aspires to improve her family's living conditions and ensure their future well-being by following the Dungganon way. 

About NWTF: In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed on a member of a community who has earned respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. 
Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking the link to the NWTF Kiva lending team on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: Additional working capital

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To buy more rice, palm oil, sugar, beans, flour, yeast, and milk, among other goods.

loans.name: Tahreer

texts.en:
Tahreer is a young woman from Jabalia Refugee camp. She is a mother of one son and is married to Mahmoud N. who appears in the picture here. 
Tahreer and her husband run a small electronic goods store selling items such as bulbs, irons, hairdryers etc. Tahreer wants to enlarge the store, fixing the space that is not used by painting it and installing shelves to exhibit more goods as well as enrich the variety they sell. Tahreer took a loan from FATEN for this purpose.

Tahreer's husband appears in the picture here as she is a conservative woman.

loans.use: To expand, improve and fix the store (Painting)

loans.name: Nicholas

texts.en: Nicholas is 44 years old and married with two children. He runs a retail shop to earn his daily bread.  He has been running this business for ten years, and he also earns extra income from his rental houses. He is looking forward to expanding his shop into a wholesale store in the future. Nicholas wants to purchase stock of sugar, rice, maize flour and wheat flour for his shop. For this reason, he has requested a loan of 20,000 KES.

loans.use: To purchase sugar, rice, maize flour and wheat flour

loans.name: Meas

texts.en:
Meas S. and his wife are local village cultivators who live in the province of Kompong Tom. He earns a living by planting many kinds of crops on his own farmland, located away from his house. He has eight children, five of whom are married. Four of the children are employed at various occupations. 

Meas S. needs a loan to buy fertilizers, and seed for growing in the dry season. He will invest the rest of the funds in his potato crop. He hopes to get more income from his farming business by using this Kiva loan.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers, seed for the dry season, and to invest in his potato crop.

loans.name: Las Lomas Group

texts.es:
La Asociación Comunal   ”LAS LOMAS”, está iniciando su primer ciclo en el Centro Focal de Los Andes.  Esta asociación comunal cuenta con la participación de diez  integrantes.  La  mesa directiva tiene como presidenta a la señora Elizabeth, como tesorera a la señora Marisol y como secretaria de actas a la señora Ximena. Las asociadas cuentan con diversos, entre ellos tenemos comercio, producción y servicio: confección de chamarras y mochilas, artesanía de alfombras, venta de alfombras, venta de comida, tejido de chompas, ayudante de albañil, venta de papa y chuño.
La presidenta, la señora Elizabeth es una mujer joven de 31 años de edad, casada, madre de tres hijos.   Esta es su primera experiencia en el trabajo con asociaciones comunales.
Desde hace varios años su negocio consiste en la  confección de mochilas y chamarras, trabajando con su esposo aprendió a realizar el negocio de elaboración de mochilas y chamarras.  El material utilizado es comprado de la Ciudad de La Paz, por mayor y los productos terminados los vende desde su casa.  Para este trabajo le ayuda la familia.  Con el monto de crédito solicitado piensa comprar “tapa costuras” y con ello mejorar el acabado de los productos que vende.
Cuando le consultamos qué es lo que más le gusta de Pro Mujer, la señora Elizabeth responde  todo”.
texts.en: The "Las Lomas" ("The Hills") community group is starting its first loan at the Los Andes regional office. This group consists of 10 members, and the board of directors has Elizabeth as president, Marisol as treasurer and Ximena as secretary. The members make a living in different industries, including commerce, production and service, for example: sewing jackets and backpacks; crafting rugs; selling rugs; selling food; weaving sweaters; working as a construction assistant; and selling potatoes and potato flour. The president, Elizabeth, is a young woman of 31, married and has three children. This is her first experience with group loans. For a number of years, she has made a living sewing backpacks and jackets. She learned the business by working alongside her husband. She buys her materials in the city of La Paz at wholesale and sells the finished products out of her home. This work helps her family. She plans to use the loan she is requesting to purchase cotton ribbon so she can improve the products she sells. When we asked her what she liked most about Kiva partner Pro Mujer, Elizabeth responded, "Everything."

loans.use: to purchase cotton ribbon to make improvements to jackets and backpacks

loans.name: Patricia Evelyn

texts.es:
Patricia, tiene 31 años de edad, reside en El Transito departamento de San Miguel, tiene casa propia donde vive con su hija de 9 años; ella administra un negocio el cual tiene 4 años de existir, su venta es de productos naturales, esencias, candelas, cremas curativas.
Actualmente necesita un préstamo para la compra de mercadería, ya que desea incrementar su inventario y su alternativa son los prestamos.
Su aspiración es tener un negocio rentable, que le proporcione ganancias para cubrir sus necesidades y las de su hija.
texts.en: Patricia, who is 31, lives in El Transito, in San Miguel department. She has her own house where she lives with her 9 year-old daughter. She manages a business which has been in existence for 4 years, selling natural products, essences, candles, and healing creams. Right now she needs a loan in order to purchase merchandise, since she wants to increase her inventory and she can only do this through a loan. Her goal is to have a profitable business that provides enough earnings to meet her needs and those of her daughter.

loans.use: to purchase merchandise.

loans.name: La Amistad Group

texts.es:
Ada pertenece al grupo comunal "La Amistad".
Ada està casada con Javier y tienen 3 hijos; su hija mayor ya esta casada y vive fuera de casa, los otros 2 hijos de 23 y 17 años respectivamente viven con ella.
Ada tiene su tienda de abarrotes (vende artìculos de primera necesidad), trabaja todo el dìa, desde la 6 de la mañana hasta las 10 de la noche. Ada es una mujer muy entusiasta y trabajadora; y decidiò poner este negocio en su propia casa por apoyar al menor de sus hijos quien sufre de limitaciones motoras por ser un joven especial; a pesar de ello actualmente èl cursa estudios tècnicos.
El prèstamo otorgado lo invertirà en comprar mercaderìa nueva que le ayude a surtir mejor su tienda.
(En la fotografìa, Ada està de pie y primera de la derecha en la segunda fila, esta vestida con chompa color marron y polo color rosa)
La socia de la foto pequeña es Martha Gladys S. R., no pudo asistir a la reuniòn por encontrarse trabajando.
texts.en:
Ada is a member of the Communal Bank “La Amistad” (The Friendship). She is married to Javier and has three children. Her oldest daughter is already married and lives outside of the home. The two other children, ages 23 and 17 respectively, still live with her.

Ada has a grocery stO. where she sells basic necessities. She works every day from 6am to 10pm. Ada is an enthusiastic and hardworking woman who decided to start this business in her home so that she could take care of her youngest child who has special needs since he suffers from motor limitations. Despite these challenges, he was able to finish his technical studies.

The loan being provided will be invested in the purchase of new merchandise so that she can better stock her stO.. In the photograph, Ada is standing on the right in the second row. She is wearing a brown sweater and a pink shirt. A small photograph of Martha Gladys S. R. appears in the corner since she was not able to attend the meeting because of work.

loans.use: to purchase merchandise.

loans.name: Tomasa

texts.es:
El Banco comunal se denomina “ QORILAZO”; Este Banco se encuentra situado en el Poblado de Cachona - Santiago, perteneciente a la Provincia y Departamento de Cusco.

La socia es la Sra: Tomasa,  la socia tiene 56 años de edad, la socia es casada y tiene 7 hijos de los cuales 6 de ellos son independientes y el menor tiene 17 años, la socia vende jora, esto permite la realización de chicha que es la bebida de los inkas, la socia compra maíz amarillo al por mayor para poder elaborar la jora, es todo un proceso y la socia no revelara su secreto, la socia requiere el préstamo para poder comprar maíz amarillo al por mayor y elaborar la jora.

La socia se encuentra agradecida y desea expresar que cumplirá de manera  disciplinadamente con los pagos de sus cuotas.
texts.en:
This communal bank is called QORILAZO and is located in Poblado de Cachona – Santiago, part of the Cusco province and department.

Tomasa is 56 years old, married, and has seven children, six of whom are on their own.  The youngest is 17.  Tomasa sells corn malt that is used to make chicha, a drink of the Incas.  She buys yellow corn in bulk to make the malt.  It’s a complete process and she will not give away her secret.  She needs this loan to buy more yellow corn.

She is grateful and would like to express her thanks and promises to be disciplined with her payments.

loans.use: la socia requiere el préstamo para poder comprar maíz amarillo al por mayor y elaborar la jora.

loans.name: Angel Oswaldo

texts.es:
Angel Oswaldo tiene 45 años, es casado vive con la esposa y los hijos en  el Cantón Guaranda Provincia de Bolívar. Tiene 5 hijos. 

Los miembros de la V.R.C.  GRUPO PUCARA se encuentra ubicada en la comunidad Pucara Parroquia Guanujo, cantón Guaranda a una distancia de 15 minutos de la oficina de la cooperativa, esta ventanilla integran 22 socios que se dedican a la agricultura, crianza de animales y a la comercialización de venta de legumbres.

Angel se dedica a la agricultura y ganadería tiene 18 cuadras de terreno, siembra papas, tiene potreros, además 10 cabezas de ganado de vacas lecheras que las comercializa. Las compras las realiza en el mercado de Guaranda y las vende en el mercado mayorista de la misma ciudad.

Solicita el crédito para la comprar de insumos y alimentación de los animales. Con el apoyo del crédito le ayudaría económicamente para suplir sus necesidades. Enfrentar desafíos como las plagas y enfermedades y la variedad del clima. Su sueño es mejorar el negocio, comprar mas ganado y ayudar a los hijos con el estudio.

Le gusta pasear con la familia y festejar las fiestas del carnaval.
texts.en:
Angel Oswaldo is 45 years old, married, and lives with his wife and children in the canton of Guaranda in Bolivar Province. He and his wife have five children.

The members of the Communal Bank “Grupo Pucara” meet in the community of Pucara, Guanujo Parish, Guaranda Canton. This area is located 15 minutes away from the office of Cooperativa San Jose. The 22 members of this group engage in agriculture, livestock breeding, and selling legumes.

Angel is a farmer and livestock breeder. He has 18 plots of land designated for growing potatoes and providing open pasture. In addition, he has 10 dairy cows that he will take to market. He purchases his supplies at the market in Guaranda and then sells his products at the wholesale market in the same city.

Angel is requesting a loan to buy supplies and feed for his animals. The support he is receiving through this loan will help meet his financial needs. Among the challenges he faces are pests, diseases, and changes in weather. His dreams include improving his business, buying more cattle, and helping his children with their studies.

Angel enjoys spending time with his family and celebrating the carnival festivities.

loans.use: to purchase farming supplies and feed for his animals.

loans.name: Policarpo

texts.es: Policarpo   es un hombre de 68 años vive en Soledad,  municipio área metropolitana de la ciudad de Barranquilla;  allí tiene un negocio donde fabrica traperos y los vende a crédito y de contado; él compra retazos de tela de franela y arma trapeadores para la limpieza de las viviendas, los cuales son de mucha aceptación entre amas de casa, pero Policarpo no las vende directamente, lo hace por kilos a empresas que completan  el producto.   Su sueño más adelante es tener una bodega con suficiente materia prima,  para que cuando llegue la escasez él esté provisionado y pueda responder oportunamente a la demanda. Su mayor desafío es cuando los retazos de tela, que son su materia prima es insuficientes en el mercado,  lo cual disminuye la producción en temporadas de mucha demanda.  Este es el propósito de adquirir su credikiva, primer financiamiento que hace a la Fundación Mario Santo Domingo, porque con esta financiación, tendrá un capital de trabajo para comprar  materias primas e insumos, producir y así gradualmente tener un stop de ellos disponibles para épocas de escasez.
texts.en:
Policarpo is a 68 year old man living in Soledad, a municipality in the metropolitan area of the city of Barranquilla.  He has a business there making mops that he sells for cash and on credit.  He buys flannel remnants and assembles mops for household use which are highly popular with housewives.  However, Policarpo doesn’t sell them directly; he sells them by the kilo to firms that finish making them.  His dream for later on is to have a warehouse with sufficient raw materials so that when scarcity comes he will be stocked and able to respond to demand in an opportune way.  His greatest challenge is when the remnants, which are his main raw material, are scarce in the market which leads to diminished production when demand is high.

This is the reason behind his Kiva loan, the first financing he’s done with Fundación Mario Santo Domingo, which will provide working capital to buy raw materials and supplies, to produce and gradually have stock on hand for those times of scarcity.

loans.use: to buy raw materials and supplies like fabric remnants.

loans.name: Mapitch

texts.en:
Mapitch is 34 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married with 3 children. 

Mapitch has a retail shop that sells snacks, biscuits, noodles and beverages. She has had this business for 5 years. She requested a loan for 5,000 PHP to buy beverages, snacks and biscuits. Mapitch is a new member of HSPFI.  

In the future, Mapitch hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy beverages, snacks and biscuits

loans.name: Stephen

texts.en:
Stephen is a 37 year old married man with five children and lives in his own permanent house in Fort Portal, Uganda.  His family dream is to educate his children to the university level.
Stephen has operated a clothing shop for four years after acquiring the initial capital from farming.  His major challenges are price fluctuations and high transportation costs.  His dream is to own his own boutique.  Stephen intends to use the loan to buy clothes to sell in his shop.

loans.use: to buy clothes for resale

loans.name: Sona

texts.en: Sona is 49 years old. She purchases and resells cows, poultry, and sheep with her husband. She has four children. Sona would like to request a loan in order to purchase additional cows to increase her inventory and to meet customer demands. She believes this will lead to greater revenue and, ultimately, to greater profit for her family. In the future, Sona would like to reinvest the earnings generated by this loan back into her business to purchase additional cows and poultry to increase her family's income further. They plan to use the increased income to fund their children's education. Sona deeply appreciates the trust and support you are giving her.

loans.use: to purchase two cattle.

loans.name: Merlina

texts.en:
Merlina is 53 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married with five children. 

Merlina has a drug store shop that sells generic and affordable drugs. She has had this business for three years. She requested a loan for PHP 5,000 to buy additional generic drugs.

Merlina is a new member of HSPFI.  In the future, Merlina hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy additional generic drugs

loans.name: Diane Krystl

texts.en:
At the young age of 29, Diane had already been blessed with two children, ages 10 and 8 years old; she is sending both to primary school. Mark (Diane's spouse) works as a local farmer. 

To add to the family's income, Diane raises hogs and sells them to the butcher in their village. She usually earns 1,500 Philippines pesos (P) with each hog. Profits are used for the daily needs of the family and to pay school fees and allowances for the children.

Diane is now requesting a loan of P9,000 to buy feed, medicines and vitamins for the hog to ensure good nutrition.

In the future, she would like to generate more income to continuously educate her children. According to her, education is the only legacy they could pass on to their children.

loans.use: to buy feed, medicines and vitamins for the hog to ensure good nutrition.

loans.name: Julia

texts.es: Julia, de 37 años; vive en concubinato con Isaias. Ambos tiene 3 hijos: Jordy, Jordan y Wilson. En unión familiar ellos viven en su casa propia, ubicada en el caserío de Bellavista Huaracayo. Hace 21 años que se dedica a la siembra de maíz, alverja, habas y papa en sus terrenos propios ubicados en el caserío de Anispampa. Lo que más le gusta de su trabajo es el apoyo que recibe de parte de su esposo.”Cuando cosecho mis sembríos, mi esposo sale a vender los sacos en el mercado mayorista de la ciudad de Tarma”, menciona. Donde trabaja el negocio de compra y venta de productos alimenticios de temporada. Asimismo se dedica a la crianza de animales menores como cuyes y conejos; los cuales vende a los pobladores de su localidad cuando lo solicitan. Además de dedicarse al negocio de compra y venta de maíz, bajado 3 veces a la semana al mercado de la ciudad, donde vende por unidad. Su principal dificultad, es la falta de capital, pues cosecha y siembra constantemente; invirtiendo en el mantenimiento constante de sus cultivos. Ella pertenece al banco comunal “Señor de Muruhuay”, y este es el noveno crédito con MFP, donde se siente gustosa de poder aportar en el desarrollo de su asociación. Además promete ser puntual con el pago de sus cuotas. Julia de recibir su apoyo; invertirá el dinero solicitado en la compra de una bolsa de semilla de alverja para su próxima siembra.
texts.en:
Julia is 37 years old and lives with her life partner Isaias. They have 3 children; Jordy, Jordan, and Wilson, and as a family in their own house in the settlement of Bellavista Huaracayo.

Some 21 years ago Julia began to plant corn, peas, beans and potatoes on her own land, located in the settlement of Anispampa.  What Julia likes best about her work is the help she receives from her husband: “When I harvest my crops, my husband goes out to sell the sacks in the wholesale market of the city of Tarma,” she mentions, where the buying and selling of seasonal food products takes place.

Julia also raises animals such as guinea pigs and rabbits and sells them to the residents of her locale upon request. In addition, she buys and sells corn, going down to the city market 3 times a week, where she sells by the unit. Julia's principal difficulty is her lack of capital, since she harvests and plants constantly, to invest in the crop maintenance. 

Julia belongs to the “Senor de Muruhuay” communal bank, and this is her 9th loan through MFP. She feels very proud to be able to participate in the development of this association. And she promises to be punctual in making her payments. Upon receiving her loan, Julia will use the money to buy a bag of green pea seeds for her next sowing.

loans.use: buy a bag of green pea seeds to plant.

loans.name: Parvana

texts.en:
Parvana lives and works in Agsu. She is a 22-year-old single woman who lives with her parents. In 2008 her family decided to open a grocery store. Being the eldest daughter, Parvana greatly helped her parents. Parvana is a very hardworking young woman, and currently she manages the family business. 

She requested 1500 Azerbaijan New Manats (AZN) to use as working capital to buy necessary inventory and increase her assortment of merchandise. Parvana has borrowed and succesfully repaid a previous loan from Aqroinvest. This is her second loan. Parvana dreams of expanding her business to secure the future of her family.

loans.use: to buy necessary inventory.

loans.name: Catalina

texts.en:
Catalina is 45 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is widowed and has three children. 

Catalina has a food shop or carenderia that sells viands like afritada, caldereta and bulalo. She has had this business for 13 years. 

She requested a loan for PHP 14,000 to buy raw ingredients for cooking viands to sell.

Catalina has been a member of HSPFI since 2010. In the future, Catalina hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy raw ingredients for cooking viands to sell.

loans.name: Betty

texts.en: Betty is a 30-year-old married woman who has six children. Three of her children attend school. Betty has a business selling clothes in Kaya Road in Yei, South Sudan. She has been in this business for five years. Betty requested this loan through BRAC South Sudan with the hopes of expanding her business. She will use the extra income from this loan to build a concrete house in the future.

loans.use: to purchase more clothes for resale

loans.name: Elsa

texts.en: Elsa is married with 3 children. She is 60 years old and lives in the Philippines. Elsa is a farmer and produces mango fruit to earn a living. She has been doing this for 15 years and she earns 10,000 PHP a month from this business. She has requested a loan of 50,000 PHP to purchase 100 liters of spray fertilizer for mangoes. Elsa has been a member of PMPC for 1 year.

loans.use: to purchase 100 liters of spray fertilizer for mangoes

loans.name: Houénagnon Grégoire

texts.fr: Houénagnon Grégoire est âgé de 39 ans et est marié à Suzanne. Le couple a quatre enfants, tous scolarisés et vivant à leur charge. Houénagnon Grégoire vit ensemble avec sa femme et ses enfants. Houénagnon Grégoire a arrêté l’école au cours primaire. Depuis une dizaine d’année, Houénagnon Grégoire exerce comme activité la charcuterie (vente de sauce faite de viandes de porc accompagné de pâte de maïs, etc.). De façon  secondaire, Houénagnon Grégoire vend des boissons dans son restaurant. Houénagnon Grégoire s’approvisionne au Bénin. Cette activité lui procure des revenus l’aidant à assurer les diverses charges de sa famille et à subvenir à ses besoins. La clientèle de Houénagnon Grégoire s’agrandit de plus en plus, et compte tenu de peu de ressources dont dispose Houénagnon Grégoire, ce dernier sollicite l’appui financier de ALIDé, en vue de rehausser son activité et de mieux satisfaire sa clientèle.
texts.en:
Houénagnon Gregory is 39 years old and is married to Suzanne. The couple has four children, all attending school and living under their care. Houénagnon Gregory lives together with his wife and children. He left school at primary level.

For the past ten years, he has been running a business selling food preparations (pork-based sauces accompanied by corn dough, etc.). Secondarily, Houénagnon Gregory sells beverages in his restaurant. He gets his supplies in Benin. This activity provides him with income that helps him to meet his own needs and those of his family.

The number of Houénagnon Gregory's customers is steadily increasing. Given his limited resources he is now seeking financial support from ALIDé in order to enhance his business and better serve his customers.

loans.use: Buy pigs and soft drinks.

loans.name: Lucia

texts.en:
This is 37-year-old Lucia from Gweru. Lucia is married with four children, two of whom are attending school. She runs a retail business selling kitchenware. The business has been in operation for five years.

She says the main challenge she faces is competition. Lucia has requested a loan of $1,200 to buy more kitchenware for resale. She says the extra income generated as a result of this loan will allow her to look after her extended family members. In the future, Lucia plans to open another shop.

loans.use: to buy kitchenware stock for resale.

loans.name: Adehinatou

texts.fr:
Adéhinatou est une femme  âgé(e) de 40ans. Elle est mariée å un  chauffeur et ont  eu 03 enfants.
Adéhinatou travaille comme revendeuse de bouillie et de beignets depuis 1994. Elle vend à ses clients dans un quartier de la place après achat des ingrédients à Lomé et à Kanté. 
Adéhinatou a requis son premier crédit de WAGES afin d’acheter du sucre, du maîs, du haricot et de l’huile servant à préparer la bouillie et le beignet.
texts.en:
Adéhinatou is a 40-year-old woman. She is married to a driver and they have three children.
Adéhinatou has prepared and sold "bouillie" (a type of porridge) and beignets since 1994. She sells her food to customers in the area after buying her ingredients in Lomé and in Kanté.
Adéhinatou has requested her first loan from WAGES in order to buy sugar, maize, beans, and oil for preparing bouillie and beignets.

loans.use: To buy sugar, maize, beans, and oil.

loans.name: Wesakulila B Group

texts.en:
Greetings from Wesakulila B Group in Western Kenya! Neddy is the facilitator of the Wesakulila B group. This group joined One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program. 

Neddy is the mother of two children. She joined One Acre Fund in order to access fertilizer and hybrid seeds and ensure food security for her family. In the recent 2011 season, Neddy had an excellent maize yield harvesting 10 bags on 1/2 an acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund, Neddy was only able to harvest two bags of maize on 1/2 acre of land. 

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Neddy and her group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance.

With income from her maize sales, Neddy will educate her children, ensure food security and invest in livestock rearing.

In 2012, the members of Wesakulila B group will each plant between ½ and 1 acre of maize. 

Neddy is pictured with her group members in the photograph as shown.

loans.use: To source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Mjini A Group

texts.en:
Edward is the facilitator of the Mjini A group. Edward and his group joined One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program.

Edward takes care of six children at home. He joined One Acre Fund to access One Acre Fund’s best prices and to ensure food security for his family. In the recent 2011 season, Edward had a good maize yield harvesting eight bags on ½ acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund, Edward was only able to harvest one bag of maize on ½ acre of land.

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Edward and his group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance.

With income from his maize sales, Edward will educate his children and invest in livestock rearing.

In 2012, the members of Mjini A group will each plant maize plots between ½ and 1 acre of land.

loans.use: To source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Esterlita

texts.en:
Esterlita is 58 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married with 5 children. 

For 5 years, Esterlita has had a shop selling personal care products such as detergent, soap & perfume. She has requested a loan of PHP 3,000 to buy personal care items to stock and sell. In the future, Esterlita hopes to improve her business.

Esterlita has been a member of HSPFI since 2011.

loans.use: to buy personal care items to stock and sell.

loans.name: Virgen De Chapi De Yanacoto Group

texts.es: Feliciana es integrante de la Alcancía Comunal “Virgen de Chapi de Yanacoto” y está conformado por 11 mujeres emprendedoras. Feliciana tiene 62 años de edad es viuda y tiene 03 hijos independiente, en el transcurso de su vida Feliciana  se ha dedicado a distintas actividades como limpieza y lavado de ropa, también a la venta de verduras la cual lo ofrecía en un mercado, pero actualmente nos manifiesta que labora en una municipalidad en el área de mantenimiento, Feliciana es una mujer empeñosa, que gracias a su trabajo a podido educar a sus hijos, y apoyar a uno de sus nietos en su educación. El deseo de Feliciana es alquilar un stand en un mercado donde pueda ofrecer especierías (condimentos) y de esta manera asegurar su vejez. En esta oportunidad solicito el crédito para mejorar su vivienda ya que piensa comprar calaminas para su techo. La Alcancía Comunal “Virgen de Chapi de Yanacoto” agradecen el crédito brindado.
texts.en: Feliciana is a member of the Virgen de Chapi de Yanacoto Communal Bank, which is made up of 11 enterprising women.  Feliciana is 62 years old; she is a widow with three independent children.  Over the course of her life, Feliciana has done different things for a living, such as cleaning, washing clothes, and also selling vegetables in a market, but she currently works in the maintenance department of a municipality.  Feliciana is a hardworking woman who, thanks to her work, has been able to give her children an education and support one of her grandchildren in his education.  Felicia's wish is to rent a stand in a market where she can sell her condiments and thus take care of herself in her old age.  At the moment, she is asking for a loan to improve her home, as she wants to buy corrugated iron for her roof.  The Virgen de Chapi de Yanacoto Communal Bank is thankful for the loan that has been offered.

loans.use: to buy corrugated iron.

loans.name: Rosmary

texts.en:
Rosmary is a hardworking entrepreneur who has a restaurant in the Philippines. She has been in business for thirteen years. She also earns more from selling fruits and vegetables.

Rosmary has been maintaining her business through her own efforts with the help of loans from NWTF. She is now borrowing 45,000 PHP through NWTF to buy ingredients and kitchenware for her restaurant.

Rosmary dreams of saving enough money to continue sending her children to college and expanding her restaurant business.

loans.use: to buy ingredients and kitchenware for her restaurant.

loans.name: Michelle

texts.en:
As a married parent of three children, Michelle works hard to support her family.

She has a business buying and selling frozen products in the Philippines, and also earns additional income from buying and selling ready to wear clothing and raising pigs. Michelle is borrowing PHP 7,000 through NWTF to buy additional stock like hot dogs, chicken nuggets and ham for her frozen products business.

Michelle has been sustaining her business activities through two past loans from NWTF. She hopes that her hard work will help her attain her dream of saving enough money to send her children to college.

loans.use: to buy additional stock like hotdogs, chicken nuggets and ham.

loans.name: Nayioma

texts.en: Nayioma is a single mother of 4 and she is 32 years old. She is the chairlady of Inkiramat women group. Nayioma attends the group’s monthly meetings and takes group work very seriously. She encourages other members to work hard, save and prepare for their children’s education. She is a time conscious lady and to discourage lateness during monthly group meetings, she introduced a penalty. She sells milk and steers at Isinya town and to two hotels in Kitengera town. Currently she has only 12 cows and she gets 30 litres of milk per day. This gives her $10 per day. Being a single mother, she has to work hard to increase her income and this is why she wants to start selling steers in order to increase her income inflow. This is the only way she will be able to educate her children and maintain good standard of living. To Nayioma and her group members, the revival of the Kenya Meat Commission is a blessing because it’s providing ready market for cattle in the whole area. They will be selling their cattle at realistic prices unlike previously where the market was limited and the buyers determining what to offer. With this in mind, Nayioma wants to increase Steers to a point where in future she will be able to rear 20 steers at a time.
